html:
Etymology[edit]

Uncertain. Has been compared with Ancient Greek βοή (boḗ, “a cry”); both perhaps evolved from a Proto-Indo-European symbolic sound root.[1]

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈploː.roː/, [ˈpɫ̪oː.roː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈplo.ro/, [ˈplɔː.rɔ]

Verb[edit]

plōrō (present infinitive plōrāre, perfect active plōrāvī, supine plōrātum); first conjugation

  1. I cry out
  2. I deplore
  3. I lament, complain

Derived terms[edit]

  • applōrō
  • complōrō
  • deplōrō
  • explōrō
  • implōrō
  • opplōrō
  • perplōrō

Related terms[edit]

  • plōrābilis
  • plōrātiō
  • plōrātor
  • plōrātus

Descendants[edit]

descendants
edit
  • Franco-Provençal: plorar
  • Istriot: piurà
  • Lombard: plürà
  • Navarro-Aragonese:
    • Aragonese: plorar, pllorar
  • Old French: plorer
    • Middle French:
      • French: pleurer
        • Antillean Creole: pléré
        • Guianese Creole: pléré
        • Mauritian Creole: plore
    • Norman plleuraïr (Guernsey), plieuther (Jersey)
  • Italian: piorare
  • Old Leonese:
    • Asturian: llorar, ḷḷorar, ḷḷurar, yorar, chorar, churar
    • Mirandese: chorar
  • Old Portuguese: chorar
    • Fala: choral
    • Galician: chorar
    • Portuguese: chorar
      • Angolar: thua
      • Annobonese: sulá
      • Guinea-Bissau Creole: tcorá
      • Indo-Portuguese: chorá
      • Kabuverdianu: txorá
  • Old Occitan: plorar
    • Occitan: plorar
    • Old Catalan: plorar
      • Catalan: plorar
  • Old Spanish: lorar, plorar
    • Extremaduran: lloral
    • Ladino: yorar
    • Spanish: llorar
      • Chavacano: llora
      • Palenquero: yorá, yolá
      • Papiamentu: yora
  • Romansch: plürar

References[edit]

  • ploro in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • ploro in Charlton T. Lewis (1891) An Elementary Latin Dictionary, New York: Harper & Brothers
  • ploro in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
  1. ^ Maria, The Law's Beginnings, p. 134
